'A day is how long it takes the sun to come back overhead...'

A day is defined as the amount of time it takes for a celestial body that rotates on an axis to complete one full rotation. Granted the Earths axis just so happens to be in such a position so that a day on earth coincides with the position of our nearest star in the sky. But that's not an absolute measurement by any means (due to the earth's rotation around the sun and the direction of its spin on its axis it actually doesn't quite exactly match up to the sun's position), and it's certainly not a viable method of measuring a day on other planets.

This answer is actually very simple. The earth does not actually orbit the sun. The sun and the earth both orbit around a point which is in the sun but not in the exact center. This is because, as the gravity of the sun pulls on the rest of the solar system, the solar system's gravity pulls back on the sun. This causes the sun to wobble back and forth. Therefore you can define an earth day as an orbit relative to this point and you can define a solar day as the length of time the center of the sun takes to orbit this point.
